qas.question: On September 15 the Luftwaffe made daylight raids on what target in London?
What two targets were the Luftwaffe trying to destroy?
What was the reason to try and draw the RAF into a battle?

answers.text: destroy their fighters in large numbers

qas.question: What was this air battle called?
The Luftwaffe lost what percentage of its bombers sent that day?

context: On 15 September the Luftwaffe made two large daylight attacks on London along the <a0_0>Thames Estuary<a0_0/>, targeting the <a1_0>docks and rail communications<a1_0/> in the city. Its hope was to destroy its targets and draw the RAF into defending them, allowing the Luftwaffe to <a2_0>destroy their fighters in large numbers<a2_0/>, thereby achieving an air superiority. Large air battles broke out, lasting for most of the day. The first attack merely damaged the rail network for three days, and the second attack failed altogether. The air battle was later commemorated by <a3_0>Battle of Britain Day<a3_0/>. The Luftwaffe lost <a4_0>18<a4_0/> percent of the bombers sent on the operations that day, and failed to gain air superiority.
